Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC FRP: Physics-Based Compact Modeling of Gallium Nitride (GaN) Devices for Advanced Power Electronics
Award.AbstractNarration:
Advances in wide bandgap materials such as silicon carbide (SiC) and gallium nitride (GaN) have led to substantial advances in power semiconductor devices and are now positioned to dominate the next generation of power electronics replacing silicon devices. This research focuses on the creation and validation of analytical models for state-of-the-art GaN power devices. The market share of GaN devices is expected to reach a staggering $15.6 billion by 2022, mainly due to growing demands in the power and energy sector, the communication infrastructure sector, and the power electronics market. GaN devices are expected to reduce overall energy conversion losses down to 1%, resulting in an annual savings of nearly $40 billion in US revenues. A high-efficiency and green energy infrastructure is vital for reducing overall expenditures and reducing the carbon footprint of the electronics industry on the environment. Silicon power semiconductor device models have been estimated to have an annual economic impact in excess of $40 million per year based on improved design productivity. The expected outcome from this fundamental research effort focuses on developing physics-based compact device models for circuit simulations that will help electronics engineers rapidly develop circuit designs and prototypes based on GaN devices. Impacts of this model will enable a side-by-side comparison of GaN and silicon devices at the design analysis phase. This in turn will likely promote increased usage of GaN semiconductor technology. The models generated by this research will be open access and made publicly accessible on the NSF Industry/University Cooperative Research Center on Grid-connected Advanced Power Electronic Systems (GRAPES).

This research will develop and validate a physics-based compact device model for GaN power devices. The model will be derived analytically, based on the physics of carrier transport in the device layers as derived mathematically and observed through finite element simulations of device structures. The model, once derived and implemented, will be validated against experimentally measured data of commercially available GaN devices taken at University of Arkansas research laboratory facilities in collaboration with the industry partners of GRAPES. Once validated, a model parameter extraction method will be created so that users of the model can execute this procedure to obtain the parameters necessary to tailor the model's behavior to specific devices they may choose to employ from the various GaN power device suppliers in the world. The characterized model, when used in circuit simulations, will help electronics engineers to design and manufacture a wide range of GaN-based circuits that will increase the penetration of GaN devices in the US power, energy, communications, and transportation infrastructure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

A compact device model for gallium nitride power semiconductor devices was developed through the research work that was carried out over the course of this three year project. The model is able to characterize the behavior of a wide range of commercial GaN devices. The high-voltage GaN devices exhibit severe non-linearity in the capacitance behavior due to the existence of field plates that are employed to suppress the peaks in the electric field. The peaking of electric field in the channel may result in premature breakdown of the transistor. The model accurately characterizes the GaN transistor’s non-linear capacitance behavior. The model also characterizes the dc on-state behavior of the device in forward and reverse conduction mode. Due to zero reverse recovery of GaN devices, the third quadrant behavior is crucial for the efficient bidirectional operation of the device in switching converters. The accurate prediction of third quadrant behavior makes the model stand out when compared to other compact models for GaN devices. The model also characterizes the temperature-dependent device behavior in first and third quadrant. The model has been validated against the switching characteristics of commercial GaN devices. Excellent convergence properties of the device model are demonstrated through high-performance transient simulations of various switching converters and inverter topologies. Some of the results from the compact model are presented in the figures 1-6.  The work will provide a knowledge base about GaN that will be available to circuit designers in industry, changing the way that they work.

 During the course of the project, a wide range of commercial GaN devices such as EPC, GaNSystems (from two companies in particular) were characterized at University Arkansas labs located at Cato Springs Research Center (CSRC).

Ultimately, this technology will increase the efficiency and performance possible with GaN and will likely improve the cost and reliability of the power electronics in utility industries.  Such efficiencies will always impact the general public and the cost and efficiency of power that impacts everyday life.

Broader Impacts

The progress of the research was presented at GRAPES semi-annual meetings throughout the course of the project.  The technology continues to receive positive feedback from GRAPES industry partners and was utilized to ensure the evolution of the project meets with the needs of time. One GRAPES member company with close ties to the UA MSCAD program has hired UA students with experience with modeling GaN devices.  They will continue to provide advice on both the modeling and device physics. They will also be able to provide GaN devices and perhaps data for model fitting.  Two additional companies who are not GRAPES members were willing to collaborate in the form of providing GaN devices for characterization. The research findings from this project were also presented at IEEE conferences such as WiPDA, APEC, and COMPEL.  Several students benefited from participation in this project.  Ramchandra Kotecha, a UA student ultimately finished a doctoral degree and is now working at the National Renewable Energy Laboratory (NREL) in Greater, Colorado.  One additional broader impact is that further development of the device characterization boards for measurements of actual GaN devices.  These boards will be used by the UA MSCAD laboratory for years to come in order to benefit other students for the purpose of measuring devices.  A new website is being developed to disseminate our models.  This will become part of the IT infrastructure in GRAPES and the MSCAD laboratory.  All current and future students will benefit from this type of project.
